Log

[!tldr] Summary [[ Vaillancourt, Maxime|Maxime Vaillancourt ]] wrote a tutorial for setting up a [[ Jekyll ]] project with their template: Max Vaillancourt’s Jekyll Template Tutorial. This is my journey following along with the tutorial.

Part 1 - Struggle with Ruby

Let’s begin! Step 0: ! [[ Max Vaillancourt’s Jekyll Template Tutorial#0 Set up prerequisites ]]

  • This led me down a frustrating path of installing [[ Ruby ]], which apparently comes installed on MacOS by default, but you can’t really use that version to develop without a bunch of sudo commands that you probably should avoid.
  • Tried to install Ruby with rbenv, and had no fun at all…
  • Double-backed, successfully installed [[ Ruby enVironment Manager|RVM ]] instead!
    • This finally made me able let me switch which ruby to output: 
      #which ruby
/Users/michael/.rvm/rubies/ruby-3.0.0/bin/ruby
  • Ok so now my version of Ruby is the correct one… 😄

Part 2 - Local Development

[[ Max Vaillancourt’s Jekyll Template Tutorial#1 Create a fork of the template repository|Step 1 ]] and [[ Max Vaillancourt’s Jekyll Template Tutorial#2 Clone your repository locally|Step 2 ]] had no problems!

And then…

! [[ Max Vaillancourt’s Jekyll Template Tutorial#3 Test out the site locally ]]

But when I tried to bundle in my new project directory, I received an errored output. See ➡️ to direct your attention

Fetching gem metadata from https://rubygems.org/.........
Using public_suffix 4.0.6

...blah blah blah

current directory: /Users/michael/.rvm/gems/ruby-3.0.0/gems/eventmachine-1.2.7/ext
make "DESTDIR="

compiling binder.cpp
In file included from binder.cpp:20:

➡️  ./project.h:119:10: fatal error: 'openssl/ssl.h' file not found
➡️  #include <openssl/ssl.h>
➡️           ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  
➡️ An error occurred while installing eventmachine (1.2.7), and Bundler cannot continue.

➡️ Make sure that `gem install eventmachine -v '1.2.7' --source 'https://rubygems.org/'` succeeds before bundling.

  

In Gemfile:
  jekyll-last-modified-at was resolved to 1.3.0, which depends on
    jekyll was resolved to 4.2.0, which depends on
      em-websocket was resolved to 0.5.2, which depends on
        eventmachine
  • Ok so we know there is an error installing the eventmachine 1.2.7 package, and it might have something to do with SSL.
  • It says try gem install eventmachine -v '1.2.7' --source 'https://rubygems.org/'
    • No luck, similar (if not exact same) issue
  • ~scours the internet~
  • GitHub user, ITJamie, with this amazing comment on a GitHub Issue

[!quote] if on an m1 mac use -- --with-openssl-dir=/opt/homebrew/opt/openssl@1.1 instead

And so I do:

[!tip] Boom.

gem install eventmachine -- --with-openssl-dir=/opt/homebrew/opt/openssl@1.1  -v '1.2.7' --source 'https://rubygems.org/'

Success! 😄 bundle works successfully and so does bundle exec jekyll serve

Part 3 - Hosting

  • Kinda skipping over this a bit…
    • Connect GitHub to Netlify
    • Connect Google Domains to Netlify
      • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cDDr-NoI5fo
  • The DNS stuff is a bit weird

Part 4 - My own invention

Given that I’ve already configured my personal notes in such a way that may not been incompatible with this system. I need to solve two things.

1. Can I have my notes folder live in a different location?

The Jekyll template requests that you place your notes to be published in a folder named _notes. I learned later that this is known as a collection. But I already have a notes folder (path) that I like to keep which enables me to access my notes from multiple devices.

Enter symlinks → With the following (templated) I was able to create a symlink inside of the project folder, and then rename it to _notes. In other words, the content in the _notes folder are actually located in a different location:

# do this, then rename the short cut to _notes
ln -s
2 Can I selectively publish notes?

Since I use my notes for everything in my life, there’s likely some content I don’t want to share. Simple to-do lists, personally identifiable information (PII), etc.

Turns out the [[ YAML front matter ]] on each note, plus the config.yaml file gives us all of the power we need to set rules about what gets published, and therefore, built for the site. I needed to make two edits to the config file to ensure the best experience:

exclude: [
'_includes/notes_graph.json',
'_notes/*.pdf',
'_notes/**/*.pdf',
'_notes/*.png',
'_notes/**/*.png',
'_notes/.obsidian/*'
]

defaults:
	- scope
		path: "_notes/**/*.md"
	values:
		layout: "note"
		published: false
  • For the exclude variable, I don’t want to build any files that aren’t .md… for now. Not sure how this will work for notes with embedded images. More on this later?
  • I added a published: false to ensure that any notes that might be lacking front matter don’t get published.

Part 5 - Trouble in paradise

I realized that I would still need to commit my private notes to the git log, even if they were marked as published: false , which means they would be available if someone wanted to go looking through previous commits.
